title: Behavioural phenotyping of C. elegans response to Keio single-gene E. coli mutants
title_html: Behavioural phenotyping of C. elegans response to Keio single-gene E. coli mutants

protocol.title: Behavioural phenotyping of C. elegans response to Keio single-gene E. coli mutants
protocol.title_html: Behavioural phenotyping of C. elegans response to Keio single-gene E. coli mutants

source.description:
Prior to each experiment replicate, inoculate 10ml LB broth media with E. coli BW25113 in an Erlenmeyer flask for overnight culture (used as negative control and for raising worms) following the protocol, Inoculating a Liquid Bacterial Culture:
(Friday, -11 days)

source.title: Inoculating a Liquid Bacterial Culture
source.description: {"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dp8ds","text":"Luria broth (LB) is a nutrient-rich media commonly used to culture bacteria in the lab. LB agar plates are frequently used to isolate individual (clonal) colonies of bacteria carrying a specific plasmid. However, a liquid culture is capable of supporting a higher density of bacteria and is used to grow up sufficient numbers of bacteria necessary to isolate enough plasmid DNA for experimental use. The following protocol is for inoculating an overnight culture of liquid LB with bacteria.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3q94f","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2j5df","text":"This is a general protocol for making a liquid bacterial culture and the following parameters need to be mentioned for a specific type of bacterial strain:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8b3jq","text":"1. Name of the bacterial strain","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5eq11","text":"2. Growth temperature","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"foi7g","text":"3. Incubation time ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8km8k","text":"4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6nan2","text":"5. Rpm of the shaking incubator","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6rceh","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]}

Remove the BW culture from the shaking incubator and place in 4°C fridge until seeding.
(Saturday, -10 days)

Remove 10 maintenance plates from storage and the BW culture from the fridge and leave to acclimate to room temperature for approximately 30 minutes.
(Monday, -8 days)

Leave under hood until dry (with lids on, timing depends on humidity).
(Monday, -8 days)

Using a platinum pick, gently pick 30-35 adult N2 Bristol C. elegans onto each of the 10 seeded maintenance plates, and store in an incubator at 20°C.
(Monday, -8 days)

Remove the adult worms after 24 hours, leaving the eggs behind to hatch into L1 larvae.
(Tuesday, -7 days)

Inoculate a further 25ml LB broth media with BW25113 bacteria for overnight culture and place in a shaking incubator at 37°C, 200 rpm.
(Tuesday, -7 days)

Remove the culture from the incubator and 15 nursery plates from storage, and leave to acclimate on bench top for approximately 30 minutes.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Wash the worms off the 10 BW-seeded maintenance plates, into two 15ml Falcon tubes.
(Friday, -4 days)

Perform an egg prep on worms in the Falcon tubes, by following the protocol for Egg Prep for Bleach Synchronization (Cabreiro Lab):
(Friday, -4 days)

source.title: Egg Prep   for Bleach Synchronization (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"c4q15","text":"Egg prep protocol for bleach synchronisation of C. elegans. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":48,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

At around noon the next day, wash L1 larvae off the empty plate and re-feed onto 15 BW-seeded nursery plates using a glass Pasteur pipette. Aim to dispense around 1000 worms per plate. Incubate at 20°C.
(Saturday, -3 days)

Fill all 96 wells in a total of 55 culture plates (for the 45 Keio library plates + 1 plate control + 9 spares) with 200μL LB broth media and 50μg/ml Kanamycin.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Remove the Keio frozen library stock plates (in batches) from -80°C, gently remove the aluminium film, and then leave the wells to defrost for a few minutes.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

source.body: To avoid damaging the bacterial stocks through repeated freeze-thawing, do not let the wells completely defrost. Just enough to be able to pick up some cells with the replicator.

source.description:
Inoculate the 96-well culture plates from the Keio stock plate, following the protocol for Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP (Cabreiro Lab):
(Wednesday, -6 days)

source.title: Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6cl0l","text":"Luria broth (LB) is a nutrient-rich media commonly used to culture bacteria in the lab. LB agar plates are frequently used to isolate individual (clonal) colonies of bacteria carrying a specific plasmid. However, a liquid culture is capable of supporting a higher density of bacteria and is used to grow up sufficient numbers of bacteria necessary to isolate enough plasmid DNA for experimental use. The following protocol is for inoculating an overnight culture of liquid LB with bacteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7pbn7","text":"This is a general protocol for making a liquid bacterial culture in 96-well plate format from frozen stock plates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9oo94","text":"The following parameters need to be mentioned for the specific type of bacterial strains inoculated:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"coanl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4v8sm","text":"     Parameters      Example        1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain      OP50        2. Growth temperature      37C        3. Incubation time      16-18hrs        4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)      None        5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)      200-220 rpm if required   ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":291,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5riap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5k9h8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4n17u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"tables","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","5_0":"","5_1":""},"colWidths":[200,200],"data":[["  Parameters  ","  Example  "],["  1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain  ","  OP50  "],["  2. Growth temperature  ","  37C  "],["  3. Incubation time  ","  16-18hrs  "],["  4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)  ","  None  "],["  5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)  ","  200-220 rpm if required  "]],"guid":"4C53DC6A8AE811EAAF890A58A9FEAC2A","legend":"","mergeCells":[],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23],"show_headers":true}}]}

Wet some tissue with MilliQ water, and wrap the culture plates in the tissue.
NB: The tissue provides humidity that aids growth, while the presence of Kanamycin should prevent contamination.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Incubate cultures overnight at 37°C (no shaking).
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Remove the imaging plates from 4°C storage and record the average weight of 3 randomly chosen plates.
(Friday, -4 days)

Ensure that the imaging plates have lost approximately 3-5% of their original weight. Place under a hood (or drying cabinet) until this is the case.
(Friday, -4 days)

Remove overnight cultures of Keio strains from 4°C storage.
(Friday, -4 days)

Place seeded plates under a hood to dry for 20 minutes, then place in an incubator at 25°C (no shaking) for 7 hours 40 minutes (total lawn growth time: 8 hours).
(Friday, -4 days)

After 8 hours, remove the plates from the incubator and store at 4°C.
(Friday, -4 days)

On the day of tracking, first thing in the morning, ensure that the imaging cave air conditioning is turned on (and there has not been a power-cut) and also the dehumidifier waste water tray is empty. Normal temperature range: 19 - 21°C, humidity: 35 - 45%. (Pre-imaging checklist)
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Turn on the COPAS machine by following Steps 1 - 16 of protocol COPAS wormsorter, to prepare and clean the machine for dispensing Day1 N2 worms:
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Fill up the tubes to 15ml with PBS 'A' and centrifuge at 1000rpm for 2 minutes.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Remove the supernatant using a Pasteur pipette.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Repeat steps
to
four more times to thoroughly rinse off any remaining BW25113 bacteria.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Re-suspend the worms and divide them equally into two 50ml Falcon tubes (for the COPAS), and fill them both up to approximately 40ml with PBS 'A'.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Dispense 3 Day 1 N2 worms into each well of the imaging plates with the COPAS following the protocol COPAS wormsorter:
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Leave the plates to dry under a hood for 30 minutes to 1 hour (until dry, timing depends on humidity), then place in incubator at 20°C until tracking (at +4 hours on food).
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

source.body: Check that worms are crawling (not swimming) on plates, and lawns look matt and not shiny

source.description:
Repeat steps
to
to prepare all 46 imaging plates (in batches of 10) with 3 worms in each well for tracking.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Record worm behaviour on the bacterial food for 15 minutes at the +4 hour timepoint (25 fps, exposure: 25000 msec, with blue-light stimulation).
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

After tracking, discard the plates in a biological waste bin.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

40 minutes prior to each tracking run (every 20 minutes, 10 runs in total), remove 5 imaging plates from the 20°C incubator and leave to acclimate in the imaging cave.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Prior to the screening the Keio library, prepare the materials needed for 6 replicate weeks of experiments:
- 330 Whatman square-well flat-bottom 'imaging' plates
- 330 Nunc™ round-bottom microwell 'culture' plates
(45 Keio library plates + 1 control plate of E. coli BW25113 + 9 spares = 55 plates per replicate)
- 90 x 150mm Petri 'nursery' plates for rearing N2 worms (15 plates per replicate)
- 60 x 90mm Petri 'maintenance' plates (10 plates per replicate)

Make a total of 7L of normal Nematode Growth Media (NGM) agar (enough to fill 55 imaging plates x 6 replicates = 330 imaging plates) following the protocol, Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)

source.title: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.title_html: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"37sqq","text":"C. elegans is maintained in the laboratory on Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) agar which has been aseptically poured into petri plates. The NGM agar medium can be poured into petri plates easily and aseptically using a peristaltic pump. This pump can be adjusted so that a constant amount of NGM agar is dispensed into each petri plate. A constant amount of agar in the plates reduces the need for refocusing the microscope when you switch from one plate to another.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7a41p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"70s5t","text":"The imaging plates can be 35mm, 60mm or 90mm in diameter depending on the assay design.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"644a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

source.body: This is best done over 2 days, in two separate batches, to avoid problems with agar cooling during dispensing.

source.description: Using the Integra ViaFill, dispense 200μL of NGM agar into each well of all of the imaging plates following the protocol, Dispensing agar into multiwell plates

source.title: Dispensing agar into multiwell plates
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fmd1o","text":"Protocol for pouring agar into 96 well plates using Integra VIAFILL dispenser. Agar should be prepared in advance, and kept in 60oC waterbath until ready to dispense, and whilst dispensing. The X, Y, Z positions for dispensing can be adjusted according to the multiwell plates being used. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":129,"length":1,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}
Leave the plates on the lab bench (with lids on) until the agar has cooled and solidified (approximately 1 hour, timing depends on humidity).
Measure the weight of 3 plates (with lids on) and record average plate weight on day of pouring.
Dry the plates under a hood (or drying cabinet) until the plates lose between 3-5% of their original plate weight (with lids on).
Store the imaging plates upside-down at 4°C until used for experiments.

source.body: Imaging plates can be stored for up to 8 weeks at 4°C.

source.description:
Pour, following the protocol for Plate pouring (
dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.6bhhaj6
):
- 35ml NGM agar into each of 60 maintenance (90mm) plates
- 50ml NGM agar into each of 90 nursery (150mm) plates
Leave under a hood until dry, then store upside-down at 4°C until used for experiments.

Place the inoculation in a shaking incubator at 37°C at 200 rpm and leave to grow overnight.
(Friday, -11 days)

Using aseptic technique, seed the 10 maintenance plates each with 400μL of BW25113 culture
(Monday, -8 days)

Seed 15 nursery plates each with 1mL of fresh BW25113 culture. Leave under hood until dry.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Remove overnight cultures from incubator and store at 4°C until seeding imaging plates later in the day.
(Friday, -4 days)

Remove overnight cultures from the incubator and repeat steps
to
to to inoculate a second round of overnight cultures from yesterday's culture plates.
NB: These 'twice removed' cultures from frozen stocks will be used to seed imaging plates for the experiment.
(Thursday, -5 days)

Seed 10μl of bacterial culture from the wells of each of the 46 overnight culture plates into the corresponding wells of each of 46 imaging plates using the Integra ViaFlo.
(Friday, -4 days)

source.body: Ensure correct plate orientation under the Integra ViaFlo, with well A1 in the top left corner!

source.description:
Remove 10 seeded imaging plates from 4°C, and dry for 30 minutes under a hood.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Remove 3 nursery plates from the incubator and wash the worms off the plates into two 15ml Falcon tubes using approximately 10ml sterile PBS 'A' buffer.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)

Perform the following steps in 5 consecutive batches of 10 plates at a time:
(Tuesday, Tracking Day)
From here on, perform the following steps weekly for each experiment replicate.

Repeat steps
to
five more times to carry out a total of 6 replicates of the screening experiment.
Check tracking checklist to ensure that all videos have been saved correctly: '/Volumes/behavgenom$/Documentation/Protocols/analysis/tracking-checklist-20210210.docx'
Make a further of 7L of normal Nematode Growth Media (NGM) agar following the protocol, Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)

description:
Protocol for screening Caenorhabditis elegans behavioural response to E. coli BW25113 single-gene deletion mutants from the 'Keio Collection', to identify behaviour-modifying mutations for follow-up analyses.
Duration of experiment: 6 weeks total (6 replicates over consecutive weeks)
